title: GeoBridge: UiB collaborative platform for GIS/RS methods in landscape analysis in a changing world
text:
GeoBridge is a collaborative initiative that connects researchers and students from diverse academic backgrounds united by a shared interest in geographical information systems (GIS) and remote sensing (RS). The platform forsters knowledge exchange in techniques applied to landscape dynamics in a changing world and aims to support interdisciplinary collaboration, research visibility, and skill development at the interface of the biosphere, geosphere, and cryosphere.

The seminars focus on spatio-temporal analyses of landscape dynamics across the biosphere, geosphere, and cryosphere, and showcase essential tools for research and real-world problem-solving.




A hands-on, immersive experience combining UAV fieldwork and geospatial analysis. title: Understanding Glacier Melt with Drones: The Case of Tapado Glacier, Chile
text:
My master‚Äôs thesis explores how supraglacial ponds and ice cliffs influence the melting patterns of Tapado Glacier in the semiarid Andes of Chile. These features, found on the debris-covered surface of the glacier, play a crucial role in how the glacier loses mass. Using a mix of historical aerial imagery, satellite data, and drone-based surveys, I built an inventory of these features from 1956 to 2023. The goal was to understand their distribution, how they form, and‚Äîmost importantly‚Äîhow they accelerate ice melt in specific areas.





Location of Tapado Complex and its landforms. The three main landforms discussed include: (1) the Tapado Complex, (2) the upper and lower debris-covered glaciers with ice cliffs in Areas 1 and 2, (3) Area 1‚Äôs thermokarst depression from 2019‚Äì2020, and (4) Area 2‚Äôs cliffed zones surveyed in 2022‚Äì2023.




The results showed that even though ponds and cliffs occupy a relatively small surface area, they have an outsized impact on glacier thinning. For instance, ice cliffs alone can increase melt rates by more than six times compared to surrounding areas.





Surface elevation changes related to supraglacial pond and ice cliff formation (5‚ÄØm bins within a 30‚ÄØm radius). Left: yearly surface lowering; Middle: change per period; Right: difference by cliff presence.




I also found that these features tend to form in areas with low surface slope and slow ice movement‚Äîkey insights into why some glacier sectors thin more rapidly than others.





Distribution of supraglacial ponds categorized by cliff presence, survey year, and local ice velocity/slope across the Tapado Complex.




Importantly, the use of drone technology (UAVs) proved to be a game-changer, offering high-resolution 3D models that captured subtle changes missed by satellite imagery.





M3C2 point cloud distances (2022‚Äì2023) for cliffed Area 2. Left panel shows RGB point cloud; right panel shows change in meters.




This research adds to our understanding of how climate change is affecting high mountain water sources. Tapado Glacier provides meltwater to over 230,000 people downstream, making it a critical resource in a region already facing water scarcity. By highlighting the importance of supraglacial features and the power of UAV-based remote sensing, this thesis offers valuable tools for glacier monitoring and water resource planning in the Andes and beyond.

title: Urban Heat Islands: A Comparison of Air and Land Surface Temperature in S√£o Paulo
text:
Our research investigated the relationship between air temperature and land surface temperature (LST) in S√£o Paulo, Brazil, focusing on how urbanization and seasonal variations affect temperature patterns across the city. We used remote sensing data to quantify the urban heat island effect and found substantial temperature differences between urban and rural areas.


Specifically, urban regions experienced temperatures approximately 5.8 to 11.5‚ÄØ¬∞C warmer than rural areas during spring‚Äìsummer, and 4.4 to 8.5‚ÄØ¬∞C warmer during autumn‚Äìwinter. These results clearly show how urban development significantly influences local climate.





Land Use/Land Cover (LULC) classification of S√£o Paulo on the right. LST thermal mapping during summer (center) and winter (left).




More importantly, this study demonstrates that remote sensing is a highly effective, affordable, and practical tool for monitoring urban climate conditions. By providing sufficiently precise spatial temperature data, our findings can directly inform urban planning strategies and environmental policies.


Ultimately, this research highlights the importance of integrating remote sensing technology to better manage and mitigate urban heat island effects‚Äîespecially in growing cities that lack a dense network of weather stations.





Comparison between Air Temperature and Land Surface Temperature during winter (left) and summer (right).
